title: Can you please help me make a decision about what to write for my research paper? - Quora

response.answer_text: Research writing develops as you write. There is always a question what to write and what not to, and this leads to confusion. Here are few tips to keep in mind while writing a research paper (based on my research experience so far): Most important: Have a feeling, I need to write the greatest research paper of all times.Each word counts: if a thought can be expressed in 10 words, never use 11.Each sentence is important: Convey as much information in less sentences.Provide enough context: The paragraph should continue the story. Always answer, why do you write this paragraph as first sentence of every paragraph.Introduction is the summary of the paper and abstract is the summary of the introduction.Conclusion is additional information to the abstract. It is meant to attract the attention of the reader to your research paper. So, don’t forget to provide the key findings, scientific methodology, and the future scope of your research.Last but not least: follow the following flow chart: Follow the next flowchart too and quickly grasp the fundamentals of research:

i'm honest to a fault, which means that i can say that i find neither topic compelling, to put it mildly. there is, in fact, massive vaults of writing on both topics and your question about the existence of these references gives me pause. from my perspective, a research paper must, by definition seek to forward and support a proposition that is, at least in some respects, novel.  i can't think of any serious scholar of american history who would argue that manifest destiny/westward expansion was good for the native americans whom it displaced and exterminated. if you were proposing to argue that perspective and to back it up with evidence, that would be interesting. the industrial revolution topic does not include a thesis from what i can tell. simply describing it and identifying in general terms its causes and effects does not constitute a research paper. what class is this for? what papers have you written that you found to be of interest and on which you received positive feedback?

With the information you're providing you seem to have a better direction for the first topic.  Both topics have been very widely covered and a simple Google, or similar, search should pull up hundreds of sources.
